_info_definition.iso_639_3_eng: Rule for the selection of terms, one can provide three lists: select one in the list, select any in the list, select all in the list.

_info_description.iso_639_3_eng:
The structure has *three possible properties* and all properties have as *value* a *set* of *term global identifiers*. At least one property must be provided and the set value must have at least one element.

- `one`: Only one element from the list.
- `any`: One or more elements from the list.
- `all`: All elements from the list.
 

The combination of these three values represents the *selection of terms*.

_info_examples.iso_639_3_eng:
```json
{
    "_rule_selection-terms_one": [one, two, three],
    "_rule_selection-terms_any": [red, green, blue],
    "_rule_selection-terms_all": [mon. tue, wed]
}
```

This selection rule implies the following conditions:

- At least *one* of `[red, green, blue]` is required.
- *One* or *more* of `[odd, even] `are required.
- *All* of `[mon, tue, wed]` are required.
  

The following are valid:

- `[red, even, mon, tue, wed]`  
- `[green, odd, mon, tue, wed]` 
- `[blue, odd, even, mon, tue, wed]`
  

The following are invalid:

- `[even, mon, tue, wed]` 
- `[green, mon, tue, wed]`
- `[blue, odd, even, tue, wed]`

_info_definition.iso_639_3_eng: Rule for the selection of properties, one can provide three lists: select one in the list, select any in the list, select all in the list.

_info_description.iso_639_3_eng:
The structure has *three possible properties* and all properties have as *value* a *set* of *descriptor global identifiers*. At least one property must be provided and the set value must have at least one element.

- `one`: Only one element from the list.
- `any`: One or more elements from the list.
- `all`: All elements from the list.
 

The combination of these three values represents the *selection of descriptors*.

_info_examples.iso_639_3_eng:
```json
{
    "_rule_selection-descriptors_one": [one, two, three],
    "_rule_selection-descriptors_any": [red, green, blue],
    "_rule_selection-descriptors_all": [mon. tue, wed]
}
```

This selection rule implies the following conditions:

- At least *one* of `[red, green, blue]` is required.
- *One* or *more* of `[odd, even] `are required.
- *All* of `[mon, tue, wed]` are required.
  

The following are valid:

- `[red, even, mon, tue, wed]`  
- `[green, odd, mon, tue, wed]` 
- `[blue, odd, even, mon, tue, wed]`
  

The following are invalid:

- `[even, mon, tue, wed]` 
- `[green, mon, tue, wed]`
- `[blue, odd, even, tue, wed]`

_info_definition.iso_639_3_eng: Rule for the selection of values, one can provide three lists: select one in the list, select any in the list, select all in the list.

_info_description.iso_639_3_eng:
The structure has *three possible properties* whose *data* is a *set* of *values* of *any type*. At least one property must be provided and the set value must have at least one element.

- `one`: Only one element from the list.
- `any`: One or more elements from the list.
- `all`: All elements from the list.
 

The combination of these three values represents the *selection of values*.

_info_examples.iso_639_3_eng:
```json
{
    "_rule_selection-values_one": [one, two, three],
    "_rule_selection-values_any": [true, false],
    "_rule_selection-values_all": [1. 2, 3]
}
```

This selection rule implies the following conditions:

- At least *one* of `[one, two, three]` is required.
- *One* or *more* of `[true, false] `are required.
- *All* of `[1. 2, 3]` are required.
  

The following are valid:

- `[one, true, 1, 2, 3]`  
- `[two, false, 1, 2, 3]` 
- `[three, true, false, 1, 2, 3]`
  

The following are invalid:

- `[false, 1, 2, 3]` 
- `[two, 1, 2, 3]`
- `[three, true, false, 2, 3]`

_info_description.iso_639_3_eng:
*Terms* are the *base class* upon which all elements of the data dictionary are created. This data definition includes the *minimum viable data structure* for instantiating *namespaces*, *types* and *enumerations*.

*Terms* require the *identification* and *documentation* sections, while the *data* section is only required by *descriptors*.

_info_examples.iso_639_3_eng:
Term example:

```json
{
    "_code_nid": "namespace",
    "_code_lid": "term",
    "_code_gid": "namespace_term",
    "_code_aid": ["term"],
    "_info_title": {"iso_639_3_eng": "Term"},
    "_info_definition": {"iso_639_3_eng": "Term definition."},
    "_info_description": {"iso_639_3_eng": "Term description."}
}
```

Descriptor example:

```json
{
    "_code_nid": "namespace",
    "_code_lid": "identifier",
    "_code_gid": "namespace_identifier",
    "_code_aid": ["identifier", "id"],
    "_info_title": {"iso_639_3_eng": "Title"},
    "_info_definition": {"iso_639_3_eng": "Definition."},
    "_info_description": {"iso_639_3_eng": "Description."},
    "_data_class": "_data_class_other",
    "_data_container": "_data_container_scalar",
    "_data_type": "_data_type_string"
}
```

Data example:

```json
{
    "_key": "record_key",
    "namespace_identifier": "Value"
}
```

_info_description.iso_639_3_eng: *Descriptors* are terms that define properties that carry values. They *inherit* all *properties* from *terms*, but add a section of attributes that *describes* the *type* of *data* they define.
